_exec_summary.SummaryText:
For futher information contact the General Manager

Risk Management Plan-Executive Summary

1.  Facility Policy:  The owners, management, & employees of Farmer Coop Gin & Elevator, Vernon Texas are committed to the  prevention any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If any accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department & other authorities to mitigate any release & minimize the impact of the release to people & the environment.

2.  Facility Informatiion:  The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers.
Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, & distributed for the direct application of fertilizer for crop production nutrients
The maximum quanity stored would be 79,000 pounds in our 18,000 gallon storage tank.

3.  The accidental release prevention program:  The facility has referred to the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage & Handling of Anhyrous Ammonia,Kk-611.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., & the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA), 29CFR 1910.111, "Storage & handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

4.  The Five-year Accident History:
There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have:
  Have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor
  to our knowledge have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, 
  or environmental damage.

5.  The Emergency Response Plan:  
The facility has:
a.  A written Emergency Action Plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;
b.  Provided state & local authorities the emergency planning & community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are preformed to assess the maintenance of saf
e conditions.  There are no additional specific  anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
